title: Priced out: The British towns where locals can't afford to buy
text:
Priced out: The British towns where locals can't afford to buy Priced out: The British towns where locals can't afford to buy FAMILIES in Britain are being priced out of areas where they grew up as rocketing house prices leave wage increases for dust, new research shows. PUBLISHED: 17:47, Tue, Oct 20, 2015 | UPDATED: 18:08, Tue, Oct 20, 2015 GETTY Brighton is the most unaffordable home for local buyers, according to research 
In some parts, workers earning a typical local wage would need to be saving for more than 100 years to afford a home, according to the research by HomeSimple.com. 
The problem is most severe in Brighton with the average home priced at £350,222, whereas residents typically earn £23,488. 
Property prices have leapt in Brighton over the last 10 years, in part thanks to an influx of London commuters unable to afford to homes in the capital and looking for a better quality of life. 
London is the area second most unaffordable to local workers, with the average home priced at £493,026, dwarfing the typical wage of £34,720. 
Average wage earners in Bristol are the third most likely to find themselves priced out with with wages at £27,394 on average, meaning it would take more than 50 years to afford the typically priced property of £274,280. Related articles Britain's homes earn FIVE TIMES more than workers GETTY In some parts of the country it would take more than 100 years to save for a deposit PA House price rises are pricing out local people 
The figure assumes that workers could put aside 10 per cent of their salary every year for a house deposit, and that the maximum mortgage loan they could secure would be four-and-a-half times their gross annual salary. 
Alex Gosling, chief executive of Housesimple.com, said: "Affordability remains a major problem across the UK. 
"Everyone knows that London is unaffordable for all but the rich or fortunate, but these figures highlight the plight of the average person looking to buy an average priced property in their local town or city. 
"The average wage earner is being priced out of their local property market, and without a serious influx of new properties coming onto the market, that’s likely to continue to remain the case." Housesimple.com 20 most expensive towns and cities on local wages Related articles
